Computing the logarithm at small heights

Mar 2, 2019

The Rezk logarithm defines a map ; Rezk gave a formula for in the case of being a height Morava -theory. He also gave a general formula for when is any -local -ring. In this post, we will study the effect of this map when is chosen to be the sphere spectrum.

Trying to study via the logarithm, however, will lead to a dead end: at , the image of is zero under the -local logarithm . To see this, we will -localize implicitly. There is a commutative diagram of -modules, coming from the analogous square of spectra:

The image of under each of the left vertical maps is nonzero, and the element is detected in both and . Moreover, the top two vertical maps are injective in low degrees (in particular, in degree ). We will compute on ; in fact: the map is zero on the element .

Let us prove this statement. The map induces a map of homotopy fixed point spectral sequences:

where the vertical maps come from the composite of -ring morphisms. Since has Adams-Novikov filtration , it is represented by an element of , so we need to understand on . There is an additive equivalence , so .

This means (and this statement needs to be fleshed out) that we only need to understand on , and not on the whole of . The claim reduces to proving that it is zero in this degree.

The statement that is not detected by the logarithm is not unexpected, since the image of is zero under the -local logarithm (note that we have fixed ). The argument is the same as above, except with replaced by . As before, it suffices to show that is already zero on . These two propositions suggest a natural conjecture:

Conjecture: The map sends to zero for all and any prime . (At the very least, this should be true for ; moreover, the composite should send to zero.)

We note, also, that . Indeed, recall that , and is represented by an element of . As in our proof that kills , it suffices to show that is zero on of the elements coming from . A computation proves that the Hecke operator acts on (which is free of rank ). A straightforward computation proves that acts by multiplication by . It follows that on is multiplication by , as desired.

More generally, we can write down a descent spectral sequence for the map . As emphasized in the proofs above, in order to understand for , we just need to understand the corresponding representatives in the descent spectral sequence, and understand the logarithm on . We know that , where . This ring admits a Hecke decomposition: . The action of the Hecke operator on is given by multiplication by , so we find that is zero on if vanishes, i.e., if there are no integral weight cusp forms for . Since is torsion-free, we can simply check this after base-changing to . Then, we find that the dimension of the space of weight cusp forms (for , but by case work there are no cusp forms for ) is if is even and is otherwise.

In particular, the first for which there is a cusp form for of weight is , and in this case, a computer calculation verifies that has a non-diagonal matrix. Therefore, is nonzero.
